The baseball team held its regular organization meeting in the
"Barn" last Thursday afternoon,
and although there was a relatively small attendance, there
was plenty of "pep," and the outlook for the coining season appears particularly bright.
Quite .a number of last year's
regulars have left the University,
and it was shown at the meeting
that there is a splendid opportunity for any new men to make
the team. Battery candidates
are especially badly needed, for
and
Defandorf
Capt. Jack
"Eggie" Gorman, the only two
regular pitchers left from last
season, are both seniors this year.
The scrub team also is going
to receive an unusually large
amount of attention this year, in
pursuance .of the policy advocated by President Goodnow that
all undergraduates be. encouraged
to engage in some spring sport.
Every Monday during the season
is going to be devoted entirely to
the scrub men, and a schedule
embracing the best prep school
teams in the vicinity is being
drawn up.
Games have already been arranged with City, Poly and Jefferson School, and it is probable
that Dunham's, Gilman's and
others will be played, as well as
several out-of-town teams, which
will give the scrubs several trips.
A regular manager and captain
for this teani will be chosen later.
Manager C. Gordqn Pitt announced that the schedule for the
'Varsity would be ready for publication in a few days, and added
that several Wednesday games
have been booked, in which new
men especially would be given a
chance to show their ability.
Practice is held in the cage
three times a week — Tuesdays
and Thursdays at 3.30 and Saturdays at 2 P. M.

The football schedule for the
coming fall, which was announced
last week by Manager Edwin B.
Jarrett, is without doubt one of
the most ambitious ever undertaken by a Hopkins team. Not
only is it very long—ten games
are to be played next season—but
the calibre of the teams to be metis much stronger than that of any
group Hopkins has had on its
schedule for several years.
The feature of the season will
undoubtedly be the game with
Brown University, never before
met by Hopkins on the gridiron.
This game, which will be played
in Providence on October 6, will
give Hopkins football enthusiasts
an opportunity to see Black and
Blue men on the field against one
of the really crack teams of the
East.
Dickinson and Carlisle, too are
relative newcomers on the Hopkins schedule, since they have not
been met, either of them, for several seasons.
The rest of the schedule is much
the same as last year's, except
that Eastern College has been
substituted for Mount St. Mary's
as the opening game. Washington College and Gettysburg have
been dropped to give place to
Carlisle and Dickinson.
The
last five games on the schedule
are exactly the same as those of
last season, save for the fact that
it is Hopkins' turn to play at
Haverford this fall.
The season's schedule:
September 29—Easterb College
at Homewood.
October 6 — Brown at Providence.
October 13 — George Washington University at Homewood.
October 20—Dickinson at
Homewood.
October 27 — Carlisle at Homewood.
November 3 — Swarthmore at
Homewood.
November 10 — Western Maryland at Homewood.
November 17 — Haverford at
Haverford.
November 24—St. John's at
Hoinewood.
November-29 — Maryland State
at Homewood.

College Pacifism.

The Collegiate Anti-M ilitarism
League, to quote its own description of itself, is "a no-war organization springing directly from
American students and educators." The present activities of
the league are directed, in. part,
towards endeavoring to shape an
active opposition among college
men to any acts of the Government which may lead to war, unless those acts are specifically approved by a referendum vote of
the nation.
One of the arguments which the
league uses in the pamphlet it is
distributing is couched in the following terms:
"To uphold national 'honor' by
declaring war, regardless of
whether or not human happiness
is increased thereby, is treason to
the civilization that has made obsolete dueling and the vendetta.
Illusions about 'loss of honor and
prestige' can form, and have
formed, a reason for. the most
senseless ,of wars. If America
now resorts to the sword, her recent efforts for peace will appear
hypocritical, or due to a priggish
'moral superiority' born of inexperience. She will have been
shamed into war by just those
conventional dogmas which she
has pretended to despise." The
It

pamphlet is entitled, "Collegians,
Protect Your Ideals!"
No better epitome than this
could be obtained of the pacifists'
stand. To them, the national
honor of our country is a thing
always to be spoken of in quotation marks; to them, it is infinitely more important that
peace be preserved than that international law be maintained.
As a matter of fact, international
law, compared .with the safety of
pelf, seems to mean nothing at
all to them. From their standpoint, the object of all civilization is essentially negative-to
prevent bloodshed, rather than to
preserve the right.
The great trouble with the advocates of peace at any price is
that they see an evil before them,
and then screw their eyes tight,
utterly oblivious to the fact that
there is an evil even greater than
the one which they fear.
The pacifists are not essentially
moral-they are essentially unmoral. The greatest ideal in the
world today is the ideal of international law-to refuse to believe that the country which deliberately transgresses the pitiably fem;' rules which it has taken
so long to establish should he
punished for its transgression, as
a criminal is made to suffer for
the murder which he has committed, does not signify a high sense
of righteousness, but a deliberate
and pernicious short-sightedness.
"If America now resorts to the
sword, her recent efforts for peace
will appear hypocritical, or due
•to a priggish 'moral superiority'
born of "inexperience"-in such
specious arguments, such loose
phrases and meaningless rhetoric
do the pacifists hide what is
really the fundamental tenet of
their belief-the superiority of individual comfort and safety to
group morality.
The plan of putting to a popular referendum the question as to
whether the Government should
protect American and international rights, or whether it should
submit in pious submission to
every viOlation of the principles
of humanity which Germany sees
fit to perpetrate, is as un-American as it is hypocritical. To establish the precedent of taking a
popular vote every time that an
American right was to be defended would be a step too ludicrous, we should imagine, to recommend itself even to the fervid

pacifist. There are certain functions of the State which are fundamental-most important of all,
the protection of the lives and
property of its citizens; the mandate for the exercise of those
functions is not founded only
upon the temporary will of the
people, but far moie upon the
basic principles for whose fulfillment a state such as ours is
called into existence. Nor, we
suspect, would the pacifists be so
insistent in asking for a national
referendum if they did not believe
that they would be able to convince the people of the practical
comforts of their ow-n "peace-atany-price" stand.
At the present time, even with
the knowledge of the Mexican
plot before its eyes, this country
is not anxious for war; it. would
rather, a thousand times, that the
submarine edict of Germany be
repealed. But, failing that, war
seems inevitable. What the pacifists fail to realize is that war
may be infinitely more righteous
than peace-that the highest duty
on earth is.fighting for the thing
in which you believe.

College Pacifism.

The Collegiate Anti-M ilitarism
League, to quote its own description of itself, is "a no-war organization springing directly from
American students and educators." The present activities of
the league are directed, in. part,
towards endeavoring to shape an
active opposition among college
men to any acts of the Government which may lead to war, unless those acts are specifically approved by a referendum vote of
the nation.
One of the arguments which the
league uses in the pamphlet it is
distributing is couched in the following terms:
"To uphold national 'honor' by
declaring war, regardless of
whether or not human happiness
is increased thereby, is treason to
the civilization that has made obsolete dueling and the vendetta.
Illusions about 'loss of honor and
prestige' can form, and have
formed, a reason for. the most
senseless ,of wars. If America
now resorts to the sword, her recent efforts for peace will appear
hypocritical, or due to a priggish
'moral superiority' born of inexperience. She will have been
shamed into war by just those
conventional dogmas which she
has pretended to despise." The
It

pamphlet is entitled, "Collegians,
Protect Your Ideals!"
No better epitome than this
could be obtained of the pacifists'
stand. To them, the national
honor of our country is a thing
always to be spoken of in quotation marks; to them, it is infinitely more important that
peace be preserved than that international law be maintained.
As a matter of fact, international
law, compared .with the safety of
pelf, seems to mean nothing at
all to them. From their standpoint, the object of all civilization is essentially negative-to
prevent bloodshed, rather than to
preserve the right.
The great trouble with the advocates of peace at any price is
that they see an evil before them,
and then screw their eyes tight,
utterly oblivious to the fact that
there is an evil even greater than
the one which they fear.
The pacifists are not essentially
moral-they are essentially unmoral. The greatest ideal in the
world today is the ideal of international law-to refuse to believe that the country which deliberately transgresses the pitiably fem;' rules which it has taken
so long to establish should he
punished for its transgression, as
a criminal is made to suffer for
the murder which he has committed, does not signify a high sense
of righteousness, but a deliberate
and pernicious short-sightedness.
"If America now resorts to the
sword, her recent efforts for peace
will appear hypocritical, or due
•to a priggish 'moral superiority'
born of "inexperience"-in such
specious arguments, such loose
phrases and meaningless rhetoric
do the pacifists hide what is
really the fundamental tenet of
their belief-the superiority of individual comfort and safety to
group morality.
The plan of putting to a popular referendum the question as to
whether the Government should
protect American and international rights, or whether it should
submit in pious submission to
every viOlation of the principles
of humanity which Germany sees
fit to perpetrate, is as un-American as it is hypocritical. To establish the precedent of taking a
popular vote every time that an
American right was to be defended would be a step too ludicrous, we should imagine, to recommend itself even to the fervid

pacifist. There are certain functions of the State which are fundamental-most important of all,
the protection of the lives and
property of its citizens; the mandate for the exercise of those
functions is not founded only
upon the temporary will of the
people, but far moie upon the
basic principles for whose fulfillment a state such as ours is
called into existence. Nor, we
suspect, would the pacifists be so
insistent in asking for a national
referendum if they did not believe
that they would be able to convince the people of the practical
comforts of their ow-n "peace-atany-price" stand.
At the present time, even with
the knowledge of the Mexican
plot before its eyes, this country
is not anxious for war; it. would
rather, a thousand times, that the
submarine edict of Germany be
repealed. But, failing that, war
seems inevitable. What the pacifists fail to realize is that war
may be infinitely more righteous
than peace-that the highest duty
on earth is.fighting for the thing
in which you believe.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTEB:

Sir—Is not this life's painful
trouble great enough?
Are we to have more woes
heaped upon us than we can bear?
Why then should the great majority of students suffer because
of the willful pranks of the few?
Why should the many suffer the
torments of the nether regions because a few love to play like
babies with a new machine? We
might ask have they ever seen a
slot machine before? Or probably
they also, for the want of a cent,
are suffering Miltonic pangs.
How much honor has the student body of this University that
it should suffer a few to throw
the whole organization into discomfort? No, the students, as a
whole, would not countenance it.
But the trouble is that the students can not always act as a
whole. Therefore these pranksters take advantage of them.
Yet, if it is not possible to
maintain a slot machine of sanitary drinking cups, and since we
all are not blessed with a locker
or a place to keep our own private cups, we must devise another
system of watering the student
body.
Is it not possible to have a sanitary fountain without a waste of
too much distilled water?

Applications for admittance to
the lecture course which Lieutenant Elliott is to conduct in preparation for examination for the

hundred (many being residents of
Westminster and other suburbs

these classes, which will 'be held
in the Civil Engineering Building
weekly for several months.
Lieutenant Elliott is much
gratified with the evident widespread popularity of the prospective course and is making every
preparation conducive to its success. Certain phases of military
science, such as topography, will
be discussed by specialists in
their subjects, and the ground
covered will be sufficient preparation to enable the entrance examinations of the Officers' Reserve Corps to be passed.
In order to take the examinations, applicants must be twentyone years old and physically fit.
It is to be understood that these
examinations are not for admittance as second lieutenants in the
Army, but merely for the possibility' of such admittance. After
being enrolled in the Officers! Reserve Corps certain obligations
are undertaken,•such as attending
one of the summer military camps
and being prepared for a call to
service in the Army.

the first examination have passed
since then; and some of the noncommissioned officers who have

the re-examination are those
ready to occupy the places of the
present "non-corns" who show
signs of slumping or indifference.
